args.content:
# Feature Tasks: Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book in Docusaurus

**Feature**: 001-book-structure-spec | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md) | **Plan**: [plan.md](./plan.md) | **Date**: 2025-01-22

## Implementation Strategy

**MVP Scope**: Focus on US1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation. This will include Docusaurus setup, basic navigation, and the first chapter with 3 lessons to establish the pattern for remaining chapters.

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

## Phase 1: Setup

Initialize Docusaurus project and basic configuration to support the book structure.

- [ ] T001 Create new Docusaurus project in repository root
- [ ] T002 Configure basic Docusaurus settings in docusaurus.config.js
- [ ] T003 Create directory structure for 10 chapters with 3 lessons each per plan.md structure
- [ ] T004 Set up sidebar navigation in sidebars.js to reflect book structure
- [ ] T005 Install and configure Algolia search plugin
- [ ] T006 Create README.md with project overview and contribution instructions

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

## Summary

I have successfully generated the tasks.md file for the Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics book project. Here's what was accomplished:

### 1. Comprehensive Task Breakdown
- Created 45 specific, executable tasks organized in phases
- Each task follows the required checklist format: `- [ ] T### [USx] Description with file path`
- Tasks are organized by user story priority (P1, P2, P3)

### 2. Phase Structure Implemented
- **Phase 1**: Setup (T001-T006) - Docusaurus project initialization
- **Phase 2**: Foundational (T007-T012) - Core features needed by multiple stories
- **Phase 3**: User Story 1 - Book Navigation (T013-T021) - Chapter 1 with 3 lessons
- **Phase 4**: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice (T022-T029) - Chapter 2 with 3 lessons
- **Phase 5**: User Story 3 - Searchable Content (T030-T036) - Search and navigation features
- **Phase 6**: Polish & Cross-Cutting (T037-T045) - Final improvements and deployment

### 3. Specific Requirements Addressed
- âœ… **Docusaurus setup tasks**: T001-T006 covers project creation, configuration, and basic setup
- âœ… **Chapter development tasks**: T013-T021 covers Chapter 1 with all 3 lessons in detail
- âœ… **Proper formatting**: All tasks follow the required checklist format with IDs, story labels, and file paths

### 4. Additional Elements
- Implementation strategy with MVP scope (Chapter 1 for US1)
- Dependencies between phases clearly defined
- Parallel execution opportunities identified
- Independent test criteria for each user story

The tasks.md file is now ready for execution, with T001-T006 being the initial setup tasks that should be completed first. The MVP scope focuses on User Story 1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation, providing a complete, testable increment of the book.

parts.text:
---
description: Execute the implementation plan by processing and executing all tasks defined in tasks.md
---

## User Input

```text
$ARGUMENTS
```

You **MUST** consider the user input before proceeding (if not empty).

## Outline

1. Run `.specify/scripts/powershell/check-prerequisites.ps1 -Json -RequireTasks -IncludeTasks` from repo root and parse FEATURE_DIR and AVAILABLE_DOCS list. All paths must be absolute. For single quotes in args like "I'm Groot", use escape syntax: e.g 'I'\''m Groot' (or double-quote if possible: "I'm Groot").

2. **Check checklists status** (if FEATURE_DIR/checklists/ exists):
   - Scan all checklist files in the checklists/ directory
   - For each checklist, count:
     - Total items: All lines matching `- [ ]` or `- [X]` or `- [x]`
     - Completed items: Lines matching `- [X]` or `- [x]`
     - Incomplete items: Lines matching `- [ ]`
   - Create a status table:

     ```text
     | Checklist | Total | Completed | Incomplete | Status |
     |-----------|-------|-----------|------------|--------|
     | ux.md     | 12    | 12        | 0          | âœ“ PASS |
     | test.md   | 8     | 5         | 3          | âœ— FAIL |
     | security.md | 6   | 6         | 0          | âœ“ PASS |
     ```

   - Calculate overall status:
     - **PASS**: All checklists have 0 incomplete items
     - **FAIL**: One or more checklists have incomplete items

   - **If any checklist is incomplete**:
     - Display the table with incomplete item counts
     - **STOP** and ask: "Some checklists are incomplete. Do you want to proceed with implementation anyway? (yes/no)"
     - Wait for user response before continuing
     - If user says "no" or "wait" or "stop", halt execution
     - If user says "yes" or "proceed" or "continue", proceed to step 3

   - **If all checklists are complete**:
     - Display the table showing all checklists passed
     - Automatically proceed to step 3

3. Load and analyze the implementation context:
   - **REQUIRED**: Read tasks.md for the complete task list and execution plan
   - **REQUIRED**: Read plan.md for tech stack, architecture, and file structure
   - **IF EXISTS**: Read data-model.md for entities and relationships
   - **IF EXISTS**: Read contracts/ for API specifications and test requirements
   - **IF EXISTS**: Read research.md for technical decisions and constraints
   - **IF EXISTS**: Read quickstart.md for integration scenarios

4. **Project Setup Verification**:
   - **REQUIRED**: Create/verify ignore files based on actual project setup:

   **Detection & Creation Logic**:
   - Check if the following command succeeds to determine if the repository is a git repo (create/verify .gitignore if so):

     ```sh
     git rev-parse --git-dir 2>/dev/null
     ```

   - Check if Dockerfile* exists or Docker in plan.md â†’ create/verify .dockerignore
   - Check if .eslintrc*or eslint.config.* exists â†’ create/verify .eslintignore
   - Check if .prettierrc* exists â†’ create/verify .prettierignore
   - Check if .npmrc or package.json exists â†’ create/verify .npmignore (if publishing)
   - Check if terraform files (*.tf) exist â†’ create/verify .terraformignore
   - Check if .helmignore needed (helm charts present) â†’ create/verify .helmignore

   **If ignore file already exists**: Verify it contains essential patterns, append missing critical patterns only
   **If ignore file missing**: Create with full pattern set for detected technology

   **Common Patterns by Technology** (from plan.md tech stack):
   - **Node.js/JavaScript/TypeScript**: `node_modules/`, `dist/`, `build/`, `*.log`, `.env*`
   - **Python**: `__pycache__/`, `*.pyc`, `.venv/`, `venv/`, `dist/`, `*.egg-info/`
   - **Java**: `target/`, `*.class`, `*.jar`, `.gradle/`, `build/`
   - **C#/.NET**: `bin/`, `obj/`, `*.user`, `*.suo`, `packages/`
   - **Go**: `*.exe`, `*.test`, `vendor/`, `*.out`
   - **Ruby**: `.bundle/`, `log/`, `tmp/`, `*.gem`, `vendor/bundle/`
   - **PHP**: `vendor/`, `*.log`, `*.cache`, `*.env`
   - **Rust**: `target/`, `debug/`, `release/`, `*.rs.bk`, `*.rlib`, `*.prof*`, `.idea/`, `*.log`, `.env*`
   - **Kotlin**: `build/`, `out/`, `.gradle/`, `.idea/`, `*.class`, `*.jar`, `*.iml`, `*.log`, `.env*`
   - **C++**: `build/`, `bin/`, `obj/`, `out/`, `*.o`, `*.so`, `*.a`, `*.exe`, `*.dll`, `.idea/`, `*.log`, `.env*`
   - **C**: `build/`, `bin/`, `obj/`, `out/`, `*.o`, `*.a`, `*.so`, `*.exe`, `Makefile`, `config.log`, `.idea/`, `*.log`, `.env*`
   - **Swift**: `.build/`, `DerivedData/`, `*.swiftpm/`, `Packages/`
   - **R**: `.Rproj.user/`, `.Rhistory`, `.RData`, `.Ruserdata`, `*.Rproj`, `packrat/`, `renv/`
   - **Universal**: `.DS_Store`, `Thumbs.db`, `*.tmp`, `*.swp`, `.vscode/`, `.idea/`

   **Tool-Specific Patterns**:
   - **Docker**: `node_modules/`, `.git/`, `Dockerfile*`, `.dockerignore`, `*.log*`, `.env*`, `coverage/`
   - **ESLint**: `node_modules/`, `dist/`, `build/`, `coverage/`, `*.min.js`
   - **Prettier**: `node_modules/`, `dist/`, `build/`, `coverage/`, `package-lock.json`, `yarn.lock`, `pnpm-lock.yaml`
   - **Terraform**: `.terraform/`, `*.tfstate*`, `*.tfvars`, `.terraform.lock.hcl`
   - **Kubernetes/k8s**: `*.secret.yaml`, `secrets/`, `.kube/`, `kubeconfig*`, `*.key`, `*.crt`

5. Parse tasks.md structure and extract:
   - **Task phases**: Setup, Tests, Core, Integration, Polish
   - **Task dependencies**: Sequential vs parallel execution rules
   - **Task details**: ID, description, file paths, parallel markers [P]
   - **Execution flow**: Order and dependency requirements

6. Execute implementation following the task plan:
   - **Phase-by-phase execution**: Complete each phase before moving to the next
   - **Respect dependencies**: Run sequential tasks in order, parallel tasks [P] can run together  
   - **Follow TDD approach**: Execute test tasks before their corresponding implementation tasks
   - **File-based coordination**: Tasks affecting the same files must run sequentially
   - **Validation checkpoints**: Verify each phase completion before proceeding

7. Implementation execution rules:
   - **Setup first**: Initialize project structure, dependencies, configuration
   - **Tests before code**: If you need to write tests for contracts, entities, and integration scenarios
   - **Core development**: Implement models, services, CLI commands, endpoints
   - **Integration work**: Database connections, middleware, logging, external services
   - **Polish and validation**: Unit tests, performance optimization, documentation

8. Progress tracking and error handling:
   - Report progress after each completed task
   - Halt execution if any non-parallel task fails
   - For parallel tasks [P], continue with successful tasks, report failed ones
   - Provide clear error messages with context for debugging
   - Suggest next steps if implementation cannot proceed
   - **IMPORTANT** For completed tasks, make sure to mark the task off as [X] in the tasks file.

9. Completion validation:
   - Verify all required tasks are completed
   - Check that implemented features match the original specification
   - Validate that tests pass and coverage meets requirements
   - Confirm the implementation follows the technical plan
   - Report final status with summary of completed work

Note: This command assumes a complete task breakdown exists in tasks.md. If tasks are incomplete or missing, suggest running `/sp.tasks` first to regenerate the task list.

---

As the main request completes, you MUST create and complete a PHR (Prompt History Record) using agentâ€‘native tools when possible.

1) Determine Stage
   - Stage: constitution | spec | plan | tasks | red | green | refactor | explainer | misc | general

2) Generate Title and Determine Routing:
   - Generate Title: 3â€“7 words (slug for filename)
   - Route is automatically determined by stage:
     - `constitution` â†’ `history/prompts/constitution/`
     - Feature stages â†’ `history/prompts/<feature-name>/` (spec, plan, tasks, red, green, refactor, explainer, misc)
     - `general` â†’ `history/prompts/general/`

3) Create and Fill PHR (Shell first; fallback agentâ€‘native)
   - Run: `.specify/scripts/bash/create-phr.sh --title "<title>" --stage <stage> [--feature <name>] --json`
   - Open the file and fill remaining placeholders (YAML + body), embedding full PROMPT_TEXT (verbatim) and concise RESPONSE_TEXT.
   - If the script fails:
     - Read `.specify/templates/phr-template.prompt.md` (or `templates/â€¦`)
     - Allocate an ID; compute the output path based on stage from step 2; write the file
     - Fill placeholders and embed full PROMPT_TEXT and concise RESPONSE_TEXT

4) Validate + report
   - No unresolved placeholders; path under `history/prompts/` and matches stage; stage/title/date coherent; print ID + path + stage + title.
   - On failure: warn, don't block. Skip only for `/sp.phr`.

response.output:
# Feature Tasks: Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book in Docusaurus

**Feature**: 001-book-structure-spec | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md) | **Plan**: [plan.md](./plan.md) | **Date**: 2025-01-22

## Implementation Strategy

**MVP Scope**: Focus on US1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation. This will include Docusaurus setup, basic navigation, and the first chapter with 3 lessons to establish the pattern for remaining chapters.

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

## Phase 1: Setup

Initialize Docusaurus project and basic configuration to support the book structure.

- [ ] T001 Create new Docusaurus project in repository root
- [ ] T002 Configure basic Docusaurus settings in docusaurus.config.js
- [ ] T003 Create directory structure for 10 chapters with 3 lessons each per plan.md structure
- [ ] T004 Set up sidebar navigation in sidebars.js to reflect book structure
- [ ] T005 Install and configure Algolia search plugin
- [ ] T006 Create README.md with project overview and contribution instructions

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

# Implementation Plan: Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book in Docusaurus

**Branch**: `001-book-structure-spec` | **Date**: 2025-01-22 | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md)
**Input**: Feature specification from `/specs/001-book-structure-spec/spec.md`

**Note**: This template is filled in by the `/sp.plan` command. See `.specify/templates/commands/plan.md` for the execution workflow.

## Summary

This plan outlines the development of a comprehensive book on Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics using Docusaurus as the documentation platform. The book will contain 10 chapters, each with 3 lessons as specified in the feature requirements. The implementation will follow the project constitution's principles focusing on hands-on learning, beginner-friendly approach, and documentation excellence.

## Technical Context

**Language/Version**: JavaScript/TypeScript (Node.js v18+), Markdown
**Primary Dependencies**: Docusaurus v3+, React, Node.js, npm/yarn
**Storage**: File-based (Markdown documents in /docs directory)
**Testing**: Content validation, link checking, build verification
**Target Platform**: Web-based documentation, responsive for desktop/mobile
**Project Type**: Web documentation site
**Performance Goals**: Fast loading (<3s), responsive navigation, accessible across devices
**Constraints**: Must follow Docusaurus documentation standards, support multiple media types, enable hands-on examples
**Scale/Scope**: 10+ chapters, 30+ lessons, code examples, diagrams, and supplementary materials

## Constitution Check

*GATE: Must pass before Phase 0 research. Re-check after Phase 1 design.*

**Constitution Principle I (Hands-On Learning First)**: PASS - Plan includes integration of code examples and practical implementations
**Constitution Principle II (Beginner-Friendly Approach)**: PASS - Plan focuses on clear, accessible content structure
**Constitution Principle III (Documentation Excellence - Docusaurus-Based)**: PASS - Using Docusaurus as required
**Constitution Principle IV (Practical Application Focus)**: PASS - Plan enables practical projects and examples
**Constitution Principle V (Modularity and Extensibility)**: PASS - Docusaurus structure supports modular content
**Constitution Principle VI (Open Science and Reproducibility)**: PASS - Plan includes downloadable code examples with open licenses

```text
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ chapter-7/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ chapter-8/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ chapter-9/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ chapter-10/
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/      # Custom React components
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ css/             # Custom styles
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ pages/           # Additional custom pages
â”œâ”€â”€ static/              # Static assets (images, code examples)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ img/             # Images and diagrams
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ code/            # Downloadable code examples
â”œâ”€â”€ docusaurus.config.js # Site configuration
â”œâ”€â”€ package.json         # Project dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ sidebars.js          # Navigation structure
â””â”€â”€ README.md            # Project overview
```

**Structure Decision**: The book content is organized in a Docusaurus project structure with each chapter having its own directory containing 3 lesson files. This follows the FR-002 requirement that each chapter must contain exactly 3 lessons and enables modular, extensible content organization as required by the constitution.

## Phase 0: Outline & Research

### Research Tasks:

1. **Docusaurus setup requirements**: Research the latest Docusaurus setup process, dependencies, and configuration options
2. **Book navigation structure**: Research best practices for organizing long-form educational content in Docusaurus
3. **Code example integration**: Research methods for embedding and displaying code examples with syntax highlighting
4. **Media integration**: Research how to properly embed diagrams, images, and potential video content
5. **Responsive design**: Research Docusaurus responsive capabilities for mobile-friendly reading
6. **Search functionality**: Research Docusaurus search options and setup
7. **Deployment options**: Research hosting solutions for Docusaurus sites

## Phase 1: Design & Contracts

### Content Development Phases:

1. **Setup Phase**: Create Docusaurus project, configure basic settings, and establish the file structure for chapters and lessons
2. **Content Creation Phase 1**: Develop the first 5 chapters (lessons 1-15) with focus on foundational concepts
3. **Content Creation Phase 2**: Develop the remaining 5 chapters (lessons 16-30) with focus on advanced implementations
4. **Integration Phase**: Add all code examples, diagrams, and interactive elements; implement cross-linking between related topics
5. **Testing Phase**: Validate all hands-on examples, check navigation and search functionality, verify responsive design

### File Structure for Chapters and Lessons:

The file structure will follow Docusaurus conventions with each chapter having its own directory containing 3 lesson Markdown files, as required by the specification (FR-002):

resultDisplay.originalContent:
# Feature Tasks: Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book in Docusaurus

**Feature**: 001-book-structure-spec | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md) | **Plan**: [plan.md](./plan.md) | **Date**: 2025-01-22

## Implementation Strategy

**MVP Scope**: Focus on US1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation. This will include Docusaurus setup, basic navigation, and the first chapter with 3 lessons to establish the pattern for remaining chapters.

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

## Phase 1: Setup

Initialize Docusaurus project and basic configuration to support the book structure.

- [ ] T001 Create new Docusaurus project in repository root
- [ ] T002 Configure basic Docusaurus settings in docusaurus.config.js
- [ ] T003 Create directory structure for 10 chapters with 3 lessons each per plan.md structure
- [ ] T004 Set up sidebar navigation in sidebars.js to reflect book structure
- [ ] T005 Install and configure Algolia search plugin
- [ ] T006 Create README.md with project overview and contribution instructions

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

args.content:
---
title: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
sidebar_position: 1
description: Understanding the fundamentals of Physical AI and its applications
---

# Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
- Define Physical AI and distinguish it from traditional AI
- Identify key characteristics that differentiate Physical AI
- Understand the theoretical foundations of Physical AI
- Recognize practical applications of Physical AI systems

## Introduction

Physical AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that interact directly with the physical world through sensors and actuators. Unlike traditional AI, which primarily processes abstract data, Physical AI must navigate the complexities of real-world physics, uncertainty, and dynamic environments.

### What is Physical AI?

Physical AI encompasses intelligent systems that perceive and act upon the physical world. These systems must contend with:
- Real-time constraints
- Sensor noise and uncertainty
- Dynamic environments
- Physical laws (gravity, friction, momentum)
- Safety considerations

### Theoretical Foundations

Physical AI is built on several theoretical foundations:
- Control theory
- Kinematics and dynamics
- Sensor fusion
- State estimation
- Motion planning
- Real-time decision making

## Applications of Physical AI

### Humanoid Robotics

Humanoid robots represent one of the most complex applications of Physical AI. These systems must maintain balance, navigate complex terrains, manipulate objects, and often interact socially with humans.

### Industrial Automation

Industrial robots perform tasks such as welding, painting, assembly, and material handling with high precision and repeatability.

### Autonomous Vehicles

Self-driving cars and other autonomous vehicles must perceive their environment, plan trajectories, and execute controls safely in real-time.

### Healthcare Robotics

Robots in healthcare assist with surgery, rehabilitation, and patient care, requiring careful interaction with human bodies.

## Hands-on Exercise

In this exercise, you will explore a basic simulation of a Physical AI system:

1. Set up the simulation environment as described in the prerequisites
2. Run the basic Physical AI agent
3. Observe how the agent responds to physical forces
4. Modify parameters to see how they affect behavior

## Summary

Physical AI represents a significant expansion of traditional AI concepts to include direct interaction with the physical world. Understanding its theoretical foundations is critical for developing effective Physical AI systems, particularly humanoid robots that must operate safely and effectively in human environments.

## Key Terms
- Physical AI: AI systems that interact directly with the physical world
- State estimation: Determining the current state of the system and environment
- Sensor fusion: Combining data from multiple sensors
- Motion planning: Determining safe and efficient movement paths

args.content:
---
title: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
sidebar_position: 2
description: Tracing the evolution of humanoid robotics from early concepts to modern systems
---

# Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
- Trace the historical development of humanoid robotics
- Identify key milestones in humanoid robot development
- Recognize influential humanoid robots throughout history
- Understand how historical designs influenced modern systems

## Introduction

The dream of creating human-like machines has existed for millennia, but the field of humanoid robotics truly began to take shape in the 20th century. This lesson explores the evolution of humanoid robots and the key developments that have shaped the field.

## Early Concepts and Mechanical Automata

### Ancient Automata

The concept of humanoid machines dates back to ancient civilizations. Greek mythology includes tales of artificial beings like Talos, and ancient engineers created mechanical devices that mimicked human actions.

### Medieval and Renaissance Clockwork

Artisans created elaborate mechanical figures (automata) that could perform simple tasks like writing or playing musical instruments. These were purely mechanical systems without real intelligence.

## 20th Century Developments

### Early Research Robots

- **WABOT-1 (1970s)**: Developed at Waseda University, considered one of the first full-scale humanoid robots
- **WABOT-2 (1980s)**: Could communicate with humans and play musical instruments

### Honda's Contributions

Honda began developing humanoid robots in the 1980s, leading to:
- **P1 (1996)**: Early bipedal robot for balance research
- **P2 (1997)**: Added upper body movement capabilities
- **P3 (1997)**: Demonstrated public transportation navigation
- **ASIMO (2000)**: One of the most famous humanoid robots, evolving over decades

## Modern Era Humanoid Robots

### Boston Dynamics

- **PETMAN (2011)**: Designed for testing protective clothing
- **Atlas (2013)**: Advanced dynamic walking and manipulation

### Other Notable Systems

- **NAO (Aldebaran Robotics)**: Small humanoid for research and education
- **Pepper (SoftBank Robotics)**: Humanoid robot focused on emotional interaction
- **Sophia (Hanson Robotics)**: Robot with advanced facial expressions

### Academic and Research Platforms

- **iCub**: Open-source humanoid for cognitive research
- **RoboCup**: Humanoid robots for soccer competition

## Challenges and Evolution

### Key Technical Challenges

1. **Balance and Locomotion**: Maintaining stability on two legs
2. **Manipulation**: Handling objects with human-like dexterity
3. **Interaction**: Communicating effectively with humans
4. **Autonomy**: Operating without constant human supervision

### Evolution of Capabilities

Modern humanoid robots show remarkable improvements in:
- Walking stability and adaptability
- Speech recognition and synthesis
- Computer vision and object recognition
- Manipulation and grasping
- Social interaction

## Hands-on Exercise

In this exercise, you will explore video demonstrations of historical humanoid robots:

1. Research and compile videos of key historical humanoid robots
2. Analyze the differences between early and modern systems
3. Identify which historical designs influenced current approaches

## Summary

The field of humanoid robotics has evolved from simple mechanical automata to sophisticated AI-driven systems. Understanding this history provides valuable context for current research and development efforts, showing how both successes and failures have shaped the field.

## Key Terms
- Humanoid robot: A robot with human-like form and capabilities
- Bipedal locomotion: Walking on two legs
- ASIMO: Honda's advanced humanoid robot platform
- iCub: Open-source cognitive humanoid robot
- RoboCup: International humanoid soccer competition

# Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
- Trace the historical development of humanoid robotics
- Identify key milestones in humanoid robot development
- Recognize influential humanoid robots throughout history
- Understand how historical designs influenced modern systems

## Introduction

The dream of creating human-like machines has existed for millennia, but the field of humanoid robotics truly began to take shape in the 20th century. This lesson explores the evolution of humanoid robots and the key developments that have shaped the field.

## Early Concepts and Mechanical Automata

### Ancient Automata

The concept of humanoid machines dates back to ancient civilizations. Greek mythology includes tales of artificial beings like Talos, and ancient engineers created mechanical devices that mimicked human actions.

### Medieval and Renaissance Clockwork

Artisans created elaborate mechanical figures (automata) that could perform simple tasks like writing or playing musical instruments. These were purely mechanical systems without real intelligence.

## 20th Century Developments

### Early Research Robots

- **WABOT-1 (1970s)**: Developed at Waseda University, considered one of the first full-scale humanoid robots
- **WABOT-2 (1980s)**: Could communicate with humans and play musical instruments

### Honda's Contributions

Honda began developing humanoid robots in the 1980s, leading to:
- **P1 (1996)**: Early bipedal robot for balance research
- **P2 (1997)**: Added upper body movement capabilities
- **P3 (1997)**: Demonstrated public transportation navigation
- **ASIMO (2000)**: One of the most famous humanoid robots, evolving over decades

## Modern Era Humanoid Robots

### Boston Dynamics

- **PETMAN (2011)**: Designed for testing protective clothing
- **Atlas (2013)**: Advanced dynamic walking and manipulation

### Other Notable Systems

- **NAO (Aldebaran Robotics)**: Small humanoid for research and education
- **Pepper (SoftBank Robotics)**: Humanoid robot focused on emotional interaction
- **Sophia (Hanson Robotics)**: Robot with advanced facial expressions

### Academic and Research Platforms

- **iCub**: Open-source humanoid for cognitive research
- **RoboCup**: Humanoid robots for soccer competition

## Challenges and Evolution

### Key Technical Challenges

1. **Balance and Locomotion**: Maintaining stability on two legs
2. **Manipulation**: Handling objects with human-like dexterity
3. **Interaction**: Communicating effectively with humans
4. **Autonomy**: Operating without constant human supervision

- Speech recognition and synthesis
- Computer vision and object recognition
- Manipulation and grasping
- Social interaction

3. Identify which historical designs influenced current approaches

## Summary

## Key Terms
- Humanoid robot: A robot with human-like form and capabilities
- Bipedal locomotion: Walking on two legs
- ASIMO: Honda's advanced humanoid robot platform
- iCub: Open-source cognitive humanoid robot
- RoboCup: International humanoid soccer competition

args.content:
---
title: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
sidebar_position: 3
description: Understanding the essential components that make up a humanoid robot system
---

# Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
- Identify the key hardware components of a humanoid robot
- Understand the software architecture of humanoid robot systems
- Explain how hardware and software components interact
- Recognize the challenges in integrating these components

## Introduction

A humanoid robot is a complex system requiring careful integration of multiple hardware and software components. These components must work together seamlessly to enable the robot to perceive its environment, make decisions, and execute actions in real time.

## Hardware Components

### Mechanical Structure

The mechanical structure provides the physical framework and joints:

- **Frame**: The rigid body that supports all components
- **Joints**: Allow movement between body segments
- **Linkages**: Connect different body parts
- **Degrees of Freedom (DOF)**: Independent movements a robot can perform

### Actuators

Actuators provide the power to move joints:

- **Servo Motors**: Precise control of position and torque
- **Stepper Motors**: Accurate angular positioning
- **Hydraulic/Pneumatic Systems**: High power for large robots
- **Series Elastic Actuators**: Compliant actuation for safer human interaction

### Sensors

Sensors provide the robot's "senses":

#### Proprioceptive Sensors
- **Encoders**: Measure joint angles
- **Force/Torque Sensors**: Measure forces at joints and extremities
- **Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs)**: Measure acceleration and angular velocity
- **Current Sensors**: Monitor motor status

#### Exteroceptive Sensors
- **Cameras**: Visual perception
- **LiDAR**: Distance measurement and mapping
- **Sonar/Ultrasound**: Distance measurement
- **Tactile Sensors**: Touch and pressure detection

### Power Systems

- **Batteries**: Mobile power source
- **Power Management**: Distribution and regulation
- **Wiring Harnesses**: Connect components safely

### Computing Hardware

- **Main Controller**: Central processing unit
- **Edge Processors**: Local computation near sensors
- **Communication Systems**: Internal and external communication

## Software Architecture

### Control Systems

The control software manages the robot's behavior:

#### Low-Level Control
- **Joint Control**: Direct control of motor positions, velocities, torques
- **Balance Control**: Maintain stability during movement
- **Trajectory Generation**: Plan smooth movements between positions

#### High-Level Control
- **Motion Planning**: Determine appropriate movements for tasks
- **Behavior Control**: Coordinate complex behaviors
- **Task Planning**: Sequence of tasks to achieve goals

### Perception Systems

- **Computer Vision**: Processing visual information
- **Sensor Fusion**: Combining data from multiple sensors
- **State Estimation**: Determining robot and environment state

### Cognitive Systems

- **Navigation**: Path planning and obstacle avoidance
- **Human-Robot Interaction**: Processing speech, gestures
- **Learning Systems**: Adaptation and improvement over time

## Integration Challenges

### Real-Time Requirements

Humanoid robots operate in real-time, requiring tight coordination between all components:
- Control loops must run at high frequencies (often 100Hz+)
- Sensor data must be processed quickly
- Decisions must be executed without delay

### Complexity Management

- Managing hundreds of degrees of freedom
- Ensuring safety during operation
- Handling sensor noise and failures
- Maintaining stability during dynamic movements

### Communication Networks

- **CAN Bus**: Common for motor control
- **Ethernet**: High-bandwidth communication
- **Real-time protocols**: Ensuring timely delivery

## Hands-on Exercise

In this exercise, you will examine the component layout in a real humanoid robot:

1. Research the component architecture of a specific humanoid robot platform
2. Identify the key hardware and software components
3. Map the data flow between components
4. Consider how the components interact during basic movements

## Summary

Humanoid robots require sophisticated integration of numerous hardware and software components. Understanding these components and their interactions is essential for developing effective Physical AI systems. The careful balance between different component types enables humanoid robots to operate safely and effectively in human environments.

## Key Terms
- Degrees of Freedom (DOF): Independent movements a robot can perform
- Proprioceptive Sensors: Sensors that measure the robot's own state
- Exteroceptive Sensors: Sensors that measure the external environment
- Series Elastic Actuators: Actuators with integrated springs for compliance
- Sensor Fusion: Combining data from multiple sensors
- Real-time Control: Control systems that guarantee response within time constraints

## Hands-on Exercise

In this exercise, you will examine the component layout in a real humanoid robot:

1. Research the component architecture of a specific humanoid robot platform
2. Identify the key hardware and software components
3. Map the data flow between components
4. Consider how the components interact during basic movements

## Summary

Humanoid robots require sophisticated integration of numerous hardware and software components. Understanding these components and their interactions is essential for developing effective Physical AI systems. The careful balance between different component types enables humanoid robots to operate safely and effectively in human environments.

## Key Terms
- Degrees of Freedom (DOF): Independent movements a robot can perform
- Proprioceptive Sensors: Sensors that measure the robot's own state
- Exteroceptive Sensors: Sensors that measure the external environment
- Series Elastic Actuators: Actuators with integrated springs for compliance
- Sensor Fusion: Combining data from multiple sensors
- Real-time Control: Control systems that guarantee response within time constraints

# Feature Tasks: Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book in Docusaurus

**Feature**: 001-book-structure-spec | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md) | **Plan**: [plan.md](./plan.md) | **Date**: 2025-01-22

## Implementation Strategy

**MVP Scope**: Focus on US1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation. This will include Docusaurus setup, basic navigation, and the first chapter with 3 lessons to establish the pattern for remaining chapters.

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

## Phase 1: Setup

Initialize Docusaurus project and basic configuration to support the book structure.

- [X] T001 Create new Docusaurus project in repository root
- [X] T002 Configure basic Docusaurus settings in docusaurus.config.js
- [ ] T003 Create directory structure for 10 chapters with 3 lessons each per plan.md structure
- [ ] T004 Set up sidebar navigation in sidebars.js to reflect book structure
- [ ] T005 Install and configure Algolia search plugin
- [ ] T006 Create README.md with project overview and contribution instructions

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

# Website

This website is built using [Docusaurus](https://docusaurus.io/), a modern static website generator.

## Installation

```bash
yarn
```

## Local Development

```bash
yarn start
```

This command starts a local development server and opens up a browser window. Most changes are reflected live without having to restart the server.

## Build

```bash
yarn build
```

This command generates static content into the `build` directory and can be served using any static contents hosting service.

```bash
USE_SSH=true yarn deploy
```

Not using SSH:

args.new_string:
# Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics Book

An accessible and comprehensive educational resource for beginners to intermediate learners studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics. This book bridges the gap between theoretical concepts and practical implementation, fostering innovation through hands-on learning experiences.

## About This Book

This educational resource covers the fundamental and advanced concepts of Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics. The book is structured into 10 comprehensive chapters, each containing 3 lessons that progressively build understanding from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

## Chapters

1. Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics
2. Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics
3. Sensors and Perception
4. Actuators and Control Systems
5. Locomotion and Balance
6. AI and Machine Learning Integration
7. Human-Robot Interaction
8. Robot Operating System (ROS) Integration
9. Simulation and Development Environments
10. Case Studies and Projects

## Installation

```bash
yarn
```

## Local Development

```bash
yarn start
```

This command starts a local development server and opens up a browser window. Most changes are reflected live without having to restart the server.

## Build

```bash
yarn build
```

This command generates static content into the `build` directory and can be served using any static contents hosting service.

## Deployment

Using SSH:

```bash
USE_SSH=true yarn deploy
```

Not using SSH:

```bash
GIT_USER=<Your GitHub username> yarn deploy
```

If you are using GitHub pages for hosting, this command is a convenient way to build the website and push to the `gh-pages` branch.

## Contributing

We welcome contributions from the community! To contribute:

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/AmazingFeature`)
3. Make your changes
4. Add your changes (`git add .`)
5. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add some AmazingFeature'`)
6. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/AmazingFeature`)
7. Open a Pull Request

### Content Contributions

For content contributions, please follow these guidelines:
- Each lesson should include learning objectives
- Include hands-on exercises with code examples when applicable
- Ensure content is accessible to beginners while providing depth for intermediate learners
- Follow the established lesson structure and formatting

### Code Examples

When adding code examples:
- Place downloadable code in the `static/code/` directory
- Use appropriate syntax highlighting in Markdown
- Test examples to ensure they work as described

## License

This book is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. Code examples are licensed separately under the MIT License.

**Feature**: 001-book-structure-spec | **Spec**: [spec.md](./spec.md) | **Plan**: [plan.md](./plan.md) | **Date**: 2025-01-22

## Implementation Strategy

**MVP Scope**: Focus on US1 (Book Navigation and Learning) with Chapter 1 implementation. This will include Docusaurus setup, basic navigation, and the first chapter with 3 lessons to establish the pattern for remaining chapters.

**Delivery Approach**: Implement the site in phases, starting with core functionality and iteratively adding content. Each user story should represent a complete, testable increment of functionality.

**Test Strategy**: Validate each user story independently:
- US1: Verify navigation between chapters and lessons with sample content
- US2: Confirm code examples and hands-on exercises are integrated and functional
- US3: Test search functionality and topic navigation

## Phase 1: Setup

Initialize Docusaurus project and basic configuration to support the book structure.

- [X] T001 Create new Docusaurus project in repository root
- [X] T002 Configure basic Docusaurus settings in docusaurus.config.js
- [X] T003 Create directory structure for 10 chapters with 3 lessons each per plan.md structure
- [X] T004 Set up sidebar navigation in sidebars.js to reflect book structure
- [ ] T005 Install and configure Algolia search plugin
- [ ] T006 Create README.md with project overview and contribution instructions

## Phase 2: Foundational

Implement core features required by multiple user stories but not specific to any single one.

- [ ] T007 Add custom styling to match brand voice requirements (accessible, approachable)
- [ ] T008 Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility
- [ ] T009 Create content templates for consistent lesson structure
- [ ] T010 Set up static assets directory structure for images and code examples
- [ ] T011 Configure content metadata to support learning objectives and difficulty levels
- [ ] T012 Set up versioning system for content updates based on feedback

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Book Navigation and Learning [P1]

As a beginner to intermediate learner interested in Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to navigate through a well-structured book with clear chapters and lessons so that I can progressively build my understanding from basic to advanced concepts.

**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by navigating through the sample chapters and verifying that content flows logically from basic to advanced concepts with hands-on exercises.

- [ ] T013 [P] [US1] Create intro.md with book overview and learning objectives
- [ ] T014 [P] [US1] Create Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics directory
- [ ] T015 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 1: Defining Physical AI: Theory and Applications
- [ ] T016 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 2: Historical Overview of Humanoid Robotics
- [ ] T017 [P] [US1] Write Lesson 3: Components of a Humanoid Robot: Hardware and Software
- [ ] T018 [US1] Implement progressive complexity flow from lesson 1 to lesson 3
- [ ] T019 [US1] Add navigation links between lessons within Chapter 1
- [ ] T020 [US1] Create cross-links to related concepts across lessons
- [ ] T021 [US1] Add learning objectives and summaries to each lesson

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - Hands-on Practice Access [P2]

As a learner who prefers hands-on practice, I want to access practical exercises and code examples seamlessly integrated with theoretical content so that I can immediately apply what I learn.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by reviewing a single chapter and verifying that each lesson contains executable examples and practical exercises.

- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Create Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Robot Kinematics directory
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 1: Forward and Inverse Kinematics with code examples
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 2: Coordinate Systems and Transformations with code examples
- [ ] T025 [P] [US2] Write Lesson 3: DH Parameters for Robot Modeling with code examples
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add downloadable code examples to static/code/chapter-2/ directory
- [ ] T027 [US2] Integrate hands-on exercises with step-by-step instructions in each lesson
- [ ] T028 [US2] Add difficulty indicators to code examples based on hardware requirements
- [ ] T029 [US2] Create troubleshooting section for common implementation issues

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Searchable and Organized Content [P3]

As a busy professional studying Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, I want to quickly search and navigate to specific topics and concepts so that I can efficiently find and reference information without having to read linearly.

**Independent Test**: Can be tested by using search functionality and navigation to locate specific concepts mentioned in the book.

- [ ] T030 [US3] Verify search functionality indexes all lesson content properly
- [ ] T031 [US3] Add tags and metadata to lessons for improved search discoverability
- [ ] T032 [US3] Create an index of key terms with links to relevant lessons
- [ ] T033 [US3] Implement breadcrumbs for clear navigation context
- [ ] T034 [US3] Add "See Also" sections with links to related topics in other chapters
- [ ] T035 [US3] Optimize content structure for search engine crawling
- [ ] T036 [US3] Test search functionality on mobile devices

## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns

Final quality improvements and cross-cutting features.

- [ ] T037 Add accessibility features to meet WCAG guidelines
- [ ] T038 Implement analytics to track user engagement and lesson completion
- [ ] T039 Create feedback mechanisms for readers to suggest improvements
- [ ] T040 Optimize site performance and loading times
- [ ] T041 Write comprehensive contributor guide for community contributions
- [ ] T042 Set up deployment pipeline to hosting platform
- [ ] T043 Conduct content review and proofreading for all implemented lessons
- [ ] T044 Add copyright and licensing information for code examples
- [ ] T045 Document build and deployment process in README.md

## Dependencies

**User Story 2 depends on:** Foundational (Phase 2) - requires directory structure and basic configuration
**User Story 3 depends on:** All previous phases - requires content to search and navigate

## Parallel Execution Examples

**Within User Story 1:**
- T015, T016, T017 can be executed in parallel by different team members
- Each lesson can be developed independently while maintaining consistent structure

**Within User Story 2:**
- T023, T024, T025 can be executed in parallel after T022 is complete
- Code examples and hands-on exercises can be created simultaneously with lesson content

**Within User Story 3:**
- Search optimization and navigation improvements can be done in parallel with content creation

parts.text:
### Task T008: Implement responsive design for mobile compatibility

The responsive design has already been implemented in the custom.css file. I added responsive media queries that adjust the layout for different screen sizes. The task is complete.

### Task T009: Create content templates for consistent lesson structure

I'll create a content template that can be used as a standard for all lessons:

args.content:
---
title: Lesson Title
sidebar_position: 1
description: Brief description of the lesson
---

# Lesson Title

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
- [Objective 1]
- [Objective 2]
